2012 Cash Converters World Cup of DartsTournament informationDates3–5 February 2012VenueAlsterdorfer SporthalleLocationHamburgCountryGermanyOrganisation(s)PDCFormatLegsPrize fund£150,000Winner's share£40,000High checkout161 (2x)Champion(s) England

(Phil Taylor and Adrian Lewis)

«2010 2013»

Darts tournamentTemplate:SHORTDESC:Darts tournament

The 2012 Cash Converters World Cup of Darts was the second edition of the PDC World Cup of Darts which took place between 3–5 February 2012 at the Alsterdorfer Sporthalle in Hamburg, Germany.

The Netherlands were the defending champions after the pair of Raymond van Barneveld and Co Stompé defeated Wales, represented by Mark Webster and Barrie Bates in the final on 5 December 2010.[1]

England (represented by Phil Taylor and Adrian Lewis) won the tournament, beating Australia (represented by Simon Whitlock and Paul Nicholson) 4–3 in a sudden-death leg.

Format[]

24 countries in the PDC Order of Merit at the end of 4 January after the 2012 PDC World Darts Championship were represented at the PDC World Cup of Darts, with 19 from the 2010 edition returning, and the five others replaced by the Philippines, Malaysia, South Africa, Croatia and Hungary. Each nation's top ranked player was joined by the second highest player of that country. For seeding, the average rankings of the players was used, with the top 8 nations automatically starting in round 2 and the other 16 nations starting in round 1.[2]

The round 1 matches were shortened from best of 11 to best of 9 legs in doubles compared to 2010. The winners of round 1 played one of the top eight ranked teams in round 2, and it used the same format as the group stage in 2010, except that the sets were increased from best of 5 to best of 7 legs for singles and best of 9 legs for doubles matches. Two singles matches and a doubles match, with 1 point awarded for a singles win and 2 points awarded for a doubles win. If the match score was 2–2 at the end of the match, then a sudden-death doubles leg decided who got through. The fixtures remained the same, the top ranked player in the country faced the second highest ranked player in the country. Another change have seen the winners of round 2 qualify for the quarter-finals, which replaced the group stage. The quarter-finals used the same format as round 2, except that the doubles matches were best of 7 legs. The semi-finals and final used the same format used in 2010, except that the sets were reduced from best of 11 to best of 7 and from best of 15 to best of 13 respectively.[3]

Prize money[]

[3]

Position (no. of teams) Prize money

(Total: £150,000) Winners (1) £40,000 Runners-Up (1) £20,000 Semi-finalists (2) £13,000 Quarter-finalists (4) £6,000 Last 16 (second round) (8) £3,000 Last 24 (first round) (8) £2,000

Teams and seeding[]

Five teams made their debut in the 2012 World Cup. South Africa became the first African team to participate, they were joined by Croatia, Hungary, Malaysia and the Philippines. They replaced the Czech Republic, Poland, Russia, Slovakia and Slovenia.[4]

Rank Country Top Two Ranked Players Start In 1 England and Round 2 2 Australia and 3 Netherlands and 4 Scotland and 5 Wales and 6 Northern Ireland and 7 Belgium and 8 Germany and 9 Canada and Round 1 10 Republic of Ireland and 11 United States and 12 Austria and 13 Sweden and 14 Spain and 15 Finland and 16 Gibraltar and 17 Denmark and 18 Croatia and 19 South Africa and 20 Japan and 21 New Zealand and 22 Philippines and 23 Malaysia and 24 Hungary and

Main draw[]

The bracket from the last 16 and the first round matches were announced on 9 January 2012.[4] The first round teams were drawn against the seeded teams with pairings announced on 25 January 2012.[5]

Results[]

[3]

Second round[]

Three points were needed to win the match. Two best of seven legs singles matches worth one point each were played, followed by a best of nine legs doubles match worth two points. If the scores reached 2–2, a sudden death doubles decider would be played to determine the winner.

England (1) Canada (9) Legs Match Score 92.28 90.46 3–4 0–1 93.40 86.50 3–4 0–2 Taylor & Lewis 90.42 MacNeil & Part 77.51 5–3 2–2 England win sudden death doubles decider tiebreaker to progress. Result 3–2

Germany (8) United States (11) Legs Match Score 83.79 82.40 4–3 1–0 79.29 81.66 2–4 1–1 Artut & Roith 92.32 Mawson & Young 90.65 4–5 1–3 Result 1–3

Wales (5) Croatia (18) Legs Match Score 91.09 71.83 4–0 1–0 97.35 89.26 4–3 2–0 Webster & Burnett 97.28 Restović and Krčmar 83.10 5–1 4–0 Result 4–0

Scotland (4) South Africa (19) Legs Match Score 91.29 84.85 4–3 1–0 94.20 86.41 4–1 2–0 Anderson & Wright 90.13 Hogan & Petersen 91.81 3–5 2–2 South Africa win sudden death doubles decider tiebreaker to progress. Result 2–3

Australia (2) Republic of Ireland (10) Legs Match Score 89.73 78.00 4–1 1–0 91.09 81.26 4–1 2–0 Whitlock & Nicholson 85.53 McGowan & O'Connor 71.47 5–2 4–0 Result 4–0

Belgium (7) Sweden (13) Legs Match Score 93.55 80.16 4–2 1–0 78.46 81.66 2–4 1–1 Huybrechts & van de Rijck 87.08 Nilsson & Caris 77.92 5–2 3–1 Result 3–1

Netherlands (3) Austria (12) Legs Match Score 87.86 88.78 4–3 1–0 87.86 90.28 3–4 1–1 van Barneveld & van der Voort 89.27 Burger & Suljović 83.38 5–2 3–1 Result 3–1

Quarter-finals[]

Three points were needed to win the match. Two best of seven legs singles matches worth one point each were played, followed by a best of seven legs doubles match worth two points. If the scores reached 2–2, a sudden death doubles decider would be played to determine the winner.

England (1) United States (11) Legs Match Score 97.26 91.41 3–4 0–1 83.49 87.21 4–3 1–1 Taylor & Lewis 85.83 Mawson & Young 83.37 4–2 3–1 Result 3–1

Wales (5) South Africa (19) Legs Match Score 98.55 71.04 4–0 1–0 99.81 101.52 3–4 1–1 Webster & Burnett 86.22 Hogan & Petersen 93.65 4–3 3–1 Result 3–1

Australia (2) Belgium (7) Legs Match Score 93.93 80.46 4–0 1–0 94.98 98.10 2–4 1–1 Whitlock & Nicholson 102.18 van de Rijck & Huybrechts 98.58 4–2 3–1 Result 3–1

Northern Ireland (6) Netherlands (3) Legs Match Score 80.10 90.09 3–4 0–1 98.28 101.40 2–4 0–2 Dolan & Mansell 88.68 van der Voort & van Barneveld 86.40 3–4 0–4 Result 0–4

Semi-finals[]

Four points were needed to win the match. Four best of seven legs singles matches worth one point each were played. If needed, it would be followed by a best of seven legs doubles match worth two points. If the scores reached 3–3, a sudden death doubles decider would be played to determine the winner.

England (1) Wales (5) Legs Match Score 95.28 108.93 1–4 0–1 105.48 82.86 4–0 1–1 96.51 86.46 4–1 2–1 93.00 87.63 4–3 3–1 Taylor & Lewis 97.59 Burnett & Webster 87.24 4–2 5–1 Result 5–1

Australia (2) Netherlands (3) Legs Match Score 94.62 87.27 4–3 1–0 83.79 100.20 0–4 1–1 95.34 91.44 4–2 2–1 89.40 74.82 4–2 3–1 Whitlock & Nicholson 89.73 van der Voort & van Barneveld 73.92 4–0 5–1 Result 5–1

Final[]

Four points were needed to win the title. Four best of thirteen legs singles matches worth one point each were played. If needed, it would be followed by a best of thirteen legs doubles match worth two points. If the scores reached 3–3, a sudden death doubles decider would be played to determine the champion.

England (1) Australia (2) Legs Match Score 97.20 89.55 7–4 1–0 93.69 91.80 7–5 2–0 105.93 97.86 7–6 3–0 84.69 82.23 4–7 3–1 Taylor & Lewis 91.59 Nicholson & Whitlock 91.68 4–7 3–3 England win sudden death doubles decider tiebreaker to win the title. Result 4–3

Television coverage[]

The tournament was broadcast by Sky Sports in the UK and Ireland, RTL 7 in the Netherlands, Fox Sports in Australia and OSN Showtime Network in the Middle East and North Africa.[6]
